paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination broaden antigen presentation and interferon signaling to sensitize tumors to anti-PD-L1 therapy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse combination therapy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 was evaluated across multiple murine tumor models to test whether tumors could be sensitized to checkpoint blockade.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse matched control cohorts
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle-treated cohorts were maintained to benchmark the combination effects in murine models.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective analysis compared prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccinated (43) and unvaccinated (87) metastatic patients receiving ICI to probe clinical correlates.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely present.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients, limiting temporal clarity.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity make it hard to interpret group differences causally.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors tested clinically.
